betsy.grammar

Class TokenUtils

  • java.lang.Object
    • betsy.grammar.TokenUtils

  • public class TokenUtils
extends java.lang.Object
    Utilities for working with Tokens. A token is a single word or punctuation mark in a sentence. It can be represented by a CoreLabel (used by the Stanford Parser) or a normal String (used everywhere else in this program).
    Author:
    jacob

    • Method Detail

      • splitSentences

        public static java.util.List<java.util.List<edu.stanford.nlp.ling.CoreLabel>> splitSentences(java.util.List<edu.stanford.nlp.ling.CoreLabel> tokens)
        Given a list of tokens, split at sentence terminators (defined by isSentenceTerminator) into sentences. Include the sentence terminator in the sentence that it terminates.
        Parameters:
        tokens - a list of edu.stanford.nlp.ling.CoreLabel's. Their values are the tokens in the sentence(s).
        Returns:
        a list of CoreLabel lists. Each list is a sentence.

      • isSentenceTerminator

        public static boolean isSentenceTerminator(edu.stanford.nlp.ling.CoreLabel token)
        Determine if the token is a sentence terminator -- a punctuation mark that ends a sentence. This includes '.' (period), '?' (question mark), '!' (exclamation point), and ';' (semicolon). Semicolons aren't really sentence terminators, but Betsy treats a sentence with a semicolon as two separate sentences.
        Parameters:
        token - the token to test
        Returns:
        true if the token is a sentence terminator or semicolon, false otherwise.

      • tokenize

        public static java.lang.String[] tokenize(java.lang.String s)
        Split a string into tokens. The string is split at whitespace characters into words, with punctuation marks treated as separate words. Characters that aren't alphanumeric or apostrophes are treated as whitespace.
        Parameters:
        s - the string to split into tokens
        Returns:
        an array of tokens. None of the strings should have whitespace, and punctuation marks should have their own tokens.

      • isWhitespace

        public static boolean isWhitespace(char c)
        Check if the character is treated as whitespace by the tokenizer. Every character that isn't alphanumeric or an apostrophe is treated as whitespace.
        Parameters:
        c - the character to test
        Returns:
        true if the character is a whitespace character

      • isPunctuation

        public static boolean isPunctuation(char c)
        Check if the character is a punctuation mark, worthy of its own token.
        Parameters:
        c - the character to test
        Returns:
        true if the character is a punctuation mark

      • detokenize

        public static java.lang.String detokenize(java.util.Collection<edu.stanford.nlp.ling.CoreLabel> tokens)
        Given a list of tokens, reconstruct a phrase. This follows the same rules as the tokenizer, but in reverse. Words have single spaces in between. Punctuation marks are given no space before them and a single space after them.
        Parameters:
        tokens - the tokens, in the form of CoreLabels
        Returns:
        the final, reconstructed sentence(s)
